This is an interesting question because it is explicitly about growth. Past numbers of sales, by themselves, are supposed to be poor guides here, since we expect them to be growing substantially. We should look for some kind of base rate or model for the GROWTH, not for the NUMBERS. OPTIMISTIC STORY
Let me frame it first in a way that makes it obvious that they will meet (and exceed) the 500k number. Here is the growth of EV sales in China, year on year [1,2,3]: 2012: 12.8k (inferred from below)
2013: 17.6k, 1.38 times more than 2012
2014: 74.8k, 4.25 times more than 2013
2015: 331k, 4.43 times more than 2014
(The links [1,2,3] give the above numbers of EVs but for some reason quote the growth factors for 2014 and 2015 as 3.2 and 3.4 respectively, I don't know why.) To reach 500k in 2016 we need growth by a factor of 1.51 over 2015. If we average the growth factors of the 3 previous years we get 3.35, more than twice the 1.51 limit. If we fit a quadratic function to the numbers above, we get a prediction of ~675k EVs in 2016. (The growth is clearly nonlinear, and quadratic is next simplest, plus fit is pretty good. An exponential fit gives nonsensically large predictions. I would very much like a story to motivate the quadratic model.) An interesting observation from the data in [1,2,3] is that sales are never more than 5% away from production; almost every EV made is sold. This would seem to indicate that the demand is there, and production is the bottleneck. News stories paint the Chinese government as eager on EV (going as far as building out and subsidizing charging networks [4]) and renewable energy more generally [5]. This suggests that they are serious about increasing production. On the political side, the Chinese minister of industry and information technology, Miao Wei, has recently been on record predicting 2016 sales to be twice those of 2015 [6]. (Like the quadratic model says!) Overall, on this optimistic story, it seems extremely likely that they will reach 500k in 2016. PESSIMISTIC STORY
Let me frame it now in a way that makes it less likely they will reach 500k in 2016. I'll start by noting that the Chinese government is notoriously bad about publishing numbers. Combing through the archives [7], the sales numbers for April, May, November and December 2015 are simply missing. In any case, the pessimistic story is based primarily on Jan/Feb 2016 sales numbers [8]: 35.7k combined. Multiplying this by six we get a prediction of only 214.2k EVs in 2016. This might be too simplistic; surely there is a seasonality in car sales. Let's try to account for it. The total sales in 2015 (331k) were 26.6 times those of Jan/Feb 2015 combined. This would lead to a prediction of 950k in 2016, which seems too high; perhaps Jan/Feb 2015 were abnormally low for some reason. Let's use March instead. In 2015 total sales were 23.4 times March sales; if this persists in 2016, where March sales were 22.9k, we predict 537.7k EVs sold total, just over the edge. This means that any logistical hiccup would probably bring us below 500k. Other reasons to not meet the 500k: (1) The economywide slowdown in China [9], which might make sales fall significantly away from production for the first time;
(2) Bad word of mouth about EVs. This year, an order of magnitude more people actually own EVs than in any previous year. If the EV experience is bad in any way, that is more likely to become known now. CONCLUSION
I am way more convinced by the optimistic story. The quadratic model can account for the observations in the pessimistic story: in a parabola, ratios of later values to earlier values are increasing. The pessimistic story has trouble explaining the observations in the optimistic story: the economywide slowdown has been going on for more than a year. Given the Chinese government's plan to produce 5M EVs a year by 2020, I assign a high probability, say 90%, to the continued building out of EV factories and infrastructure. The models I can think of for this scenario predict a YES answer with near 100% certainty. On the other hand, if they stopped building new EV factories in March, there is still a decent chance --- more than 50%, say --- that they'd meet the 500k target. So I'm calling this one a 95% YES.
